description.text:
I needed to move my amp rack back a couple feet but the cables weren't long enough, my solution was to move my speakon connectors from the back of the rack to the front as the individual speaker leads were easier to lengthen than the 8 conductor speakon cable.

It fits the 8 conductor speakon flanged outlet nicely.

This here is a outboard motor steering stabiliser assembly that I designed to make sure that the steering returned to center should my hand not be on it for a moment.
I dont think that print settings are particularly important in this.
For mine I chose 3 perimiter and top/ bottom layers with 30% infill.
Initially I have made it in PLA which seems to have performed well but in the longer term I may cast it in aluminium or re print it in PETG.
The assembly clamps over your outboard motor handle below the throttle and then uses bungy elastic cords and clips to attach it to the corners at the rear of the boat.
Not only does the setup return the motor to a central direction but it also assist in new users piloting the boat who might otherwise find the default setup a little too responsive.
This has been designed to fit on my Evinrude 20hp (of unknown year) and may well not work on your motor but it is not difficult to design one for your particular motor.

To quote Kenny Powers, "Before you say anything, prepare to shut the f**k up!" Yes, this is a Confederate object. Who cares? Let's not make this political. I'm sure that like myself, most others on here can appreciate the engineering behind this submarine and the fact that its a really cool model.

So, this is the C.S.S. Hunley, though it played a small part in the war itself, it was the first combat submarine to ever sink an enemy vessel, and it paved the way for all submarine warfare that would come in the future by demonstrating that it was a technology worth advancing. It has quite an interesting history, and is well worth the read.

You can learn some about it here :

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._L._Hunley_(submarine)

As far as the model itself, I did not design it. I did however convert it into a 3D model, then into a printable STL, then add a few details, scale it, and repair it. All because I want to build it, and now YOU can too! The only thing I would have liked to add to it would have been a stand, hopefully someone better at this stuff than me will do just that!

This is piece of horizontal stabiliser and piece of fuselage from 3D printed RC plane KRAGA Maripi. If you are able to print this part you should be able to print whole plane.

KRAGA Maripi is 1.1m big acrobat which is printed on 3D printer and reinforced with carbon spars.

More info at https://www.3DprintedRCplanes.com/maripi

Video of assembled plane: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T8RgL5h8tJ0&t

The file is available also here: https://3dprintedrcplanes.com/download_test/maripi/

Rafts:

Yes

Notes:

The red one has to be printed as shell - 0% infill and no horizontal surfaces (thickness of the shell is one layer). Only this way you can achieve required weight of the plane.

The grey one has to be printed as solid - 100% infill.

Nozzle: 0.4 mm
Layer thickness: 0.19 mm
Rafts: yes
Use the default orientation and whatever printing material.

Result verification

Red part should weight 8 g. The wall of the shell should be printed by one pass of printing head so that the shell is very thin. You should be able to fit carbon tubes with diameter of 3 mm and 2 mm into spar leading holes.

Grey part should weight 16 g and you should be able to fit carbon tube with diameter of 2 mm into all 4 spar leading holes. There might be small printing imperfections making it difficult to insert carbon spar all the way through the part but in written build guide I'm describing a way how to clear the holes using for example a spoke from bicycle wheel.

I strongly recommend to cover both parts with covering film to test if material of your choice will not deform from ironing heat and if covering film will stick on it (I tested many materials with multiple covering film brands without issues but it can theoretically happen).

Another from my file vault is this killer 1918 Fordson Model F Tractor. I've no idea who designed it originally, but it was a solid drawing for sure. I had it as a dae file and when I converted it to an STL to print it, it came back as a jumbled mess. Every part of the tractor was superimposed on top of one another right in the middle of the thing. I spent quite awhile chopping it apart and melding it into proper form. I wanted to print it for my collection, and now so can YOU! I scaled it to some pretty huge proportions because I want it to stand out, Ford tractors are the tits! You can scale it however you want with this file. Back in the day this versatile machine was outfitted for virtually every job with countless implements, both factory made and one-off. This makes for an almost endless amount of remixes and add-ons a skilled 3D designer could make. I'd love to have a few!

Read about this early machine here :

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fordson#Fordson_origins.2C_Model_F.2C_and_Model_N

title: Retractable Pen (Fully-functional)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: It's just a simple retractable pen that works. You need a spring and an ink refill but the refill is the thicker type you find in larger retractable pens (see images above), not the smaller type you find in cheap capped pens. The button piece is somewhat prone to breaking so any help on creating a more durable button piece is greatly appreciated. Remixes are welcome!

Printer:

HORI Z300

Rafts:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

At least 20%

Notes:

Higher resolution is better, it will let the pieces slide more easily. Print both pieces vertically, the main body should be printed with tip facing up. Use a brim or a raft or else your print likely isn't going to stick.

Assembly Instructions

1 - Insert the spring into the main body of the pen
2 - Insert the ink refill
3 - Put in the small cylindrical insert
4 - Insert the button piece
5 - To use the pen, press the button down like a normal retractable pen
6 - Retract it by pushing inwards on the lower hole with your fingernail (it won't be very smooth at first because it takes a bit of breaking in)

title: Anet A6 Frame Brace/Stiffening System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Anet A6 frame stiffening system. This stiffener will mount your printer to a 20"x20" or larger flat surface. I used a nice thick slab of 1-1/8" MDF veneer, sitting on 4 rubber feet. You will need four 3 x 20mm bolts, and 4 pieces of 5/16 threaded rod. Two pieces at 18" and two at 16.5". All of the parts print with very little support when printed on their sides, but be careful. I cracked one of my bases with a mounting screw. Probably stronger printed flat. Also, remember PLA and acrylic are very brittle. Be very careful/gentle tightening everything. Don't crack your frame! The A6 already has a great frame, better than the a8. The point of this upgrade is to pull the whole thing down tight and increase mass. This should help with printing at speed and allow the frame to absorb larger jerk and accelerations.

Amazon parts links:
5/16" x 24" rod Threaded http://amzn.to/2AnzjNy
5/16" nuts http://amzn.to/2jCKnOT
5/16" wing nuts http://amzn.to/2AxTg6U

description.text:
Based on the original Prusa i3 Titan Extruder assembly.

If your going for print speed on an i3 style printer this mount is a good place to start.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=clixTeZ3fJA

  • Corrected spacing for Anets smooth rods ( 46,3mm center - center - Injection molded holders )

  • Added huge Z offset to bring the assembly high enough for the E3D V6 while not wasting z height, actually you will gain about 10mm Z height vs the stock Anet assembly.

  • I highly advice against using Igus bearings like i did first, they dont work properly on the A8 smooth rods and will wear quickly.

Reach around fan duct only fits the smallest pancake stepper, so you need to run a different controller, the standard Anet board cant drive 1.7A steppers.

Doing this conversion you reduce the extruder weight by 300g !

Printer:

Diy Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print without supports !

Fan Holders:

  • V1.4: Repaired model, improved tip shape

  • V1.4 plus 1: Same as 1.4 - lowered tip by 1mm
Titan Mount:

  • V2: Reinforced / braced extruder holder, added through holes so hot vent air can escape

  • V2.1: Improved printability, holder assembly is now printable without any supports

  • V2.2: Added a row of zip tie holders to the assembly for cable management

  • V3: Cleaned up the model, removed the Pinda holder and added a zip tie holder to hugely reinforce the structure / reduce ringing.

  • V3.x: In the future i might do a way to universially mount different Auto Bed Leveling probes but in the context that the Anet Bed is really small the only benefit of auto bed leveling is that the cheap TR8 nuts degrade faster so its not exactly my priority. Another planned and certain improvement will be the ability to use 4 instead of just 3 bearings.

• Ziptie the lot together.

  • Break off the belt loop holders, they become self tightening once loose.

  • Tighten the belt so it plays like a violin.

  • Print fast

comments.text: I have tried both the 2.2 and 3 versions of these carriages and it just seems that my Aug 2017 V6+Titan setup just doesn't work with either version of these carriages.  Because there are no provisions for making the setup longer or shorter (as the nozzle and heatbreak need to mesh and the V6 mounts only one way in the extruder), I am not entirely sure what is happening.  I am guessing that E3D changed the size of either the Titan, the V6 or both somewhere along the line...   I know they changed the heatblock to support a themastor in a cartridge, but that doesn't change the need to have the nozzle and heatbreak from being meshed unless they changed the heatbreak too.  The fan extends waaay beyond the nozzle so I cannot use the fan with on the new carriage (indicating mine is too short) and I can barely fit the 40mm fan mount which almost looks like the Titan is shallower and hugging tighter to the wall.  I am going to see if there are schematics that show the product modifications over time.  I really want to use this mount, but it has been a journey  lol  My printer is very well calibrated and generally prints to size.  The bearing hook ups work perfectly so I am pretty sure I am not dealing with a printer hardware or setting issue.  lol

title: HTC Vive Controller Golf Club Handle Mount for use with The Golf Club VR

description.text:
Created to be used specifically with The Golf Club VR golf sim as it allows you to offset the Y-axis of the Vive controller in relation to the virtual club. Because it can only offset the one axis, the physical golf club grip needs to be inline with the Vive controller in order to feel accurate in the game.

https://youtu.be/_iiF_mWKUE8

Pieces of dwoodle's design were used as a base for the Vive controller mount portion. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2071035

Printing:
Important that the base pieces are printed on their side as illustrated in the included picture and using 4-5 perimeters for strength. I used an infill of 30% and it's plenty strong.

Assembly:
You will need 6 M4 screws of various lengths to attach all the pieces. I am using an old 4 Iron club cut 8cm down the shaft below the grip. Holes need to be drilled through the club shaft, use the printed Base_ClubMountSide.STL as a guide for drilling the holes.

From the file vault is this 1937 Stalinetz S-65 Tractor. I didn't design it at all, I've only converted it to STL format for printing, then repaired it and scaled it way up. The cut-out fella standing there in the STL isn't present in the scaled up 3mf file. I wanted a big Russian tractor to add to my collection, and now YOU can make one too! The big downfall with this model is that it is lacking tread detail. I can't fix it yet and I'm really hoping that someone here will. From what I understand these tractors while very slow, were an irreplaceable part of the Red Army fleet. They were outfitted with a vast assortment of equipment both factory made and field-modified. This leaves tons of room for remixes including closed-cab variants and wood-gas conversions. I'd love to see some stuff like that!

Read about this cool old tractor here :

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-65_Stalinets

print_settings.Notes:: I made two mirror parts in CURA to have all screws point inwards. You may also do that, but it's not necessary.

description.text:
After install my printer in a wobbling table, the oscillations in Y axis direction was very obvious.
Printer will be set in a much stronger table but, nevertheless, that will always be the weakest part of the printer (bed has a substantial inertia and high speeds/acceleration will always create vibrations is this axis).
On the other hand, X axis already stronger and with much less mass to push-pull around.

Uses:

  • 2x 445 mm carbon rod (diameters: 10mm ouside, 8mm inside)
  • 4x M3x12mm screws with nuts.
  • 8x M4x8mm screws with T-Nuts.

All my TRONXY X3 mods referenced here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2436602

Printer:

TRONXY X3

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Lower part: printer in normal position, without supports
Higher part: printed in vertical position (must be rotated), point down, with support (could had done without them, but wish these parts to be aesthetically coherent with my other parts).

I made two mirror parts in CURA to have all screws point inwards. You may also do that, but it's not necessary.

Slicer settings

My CURA settings have a -0.07mm "Horizontal Expansion". Gives a perfect fit very time.
If printed without this compensation, most prints will have smaller than ideal 10.1mm hole. Keep this in mind and adjust your slicer accordingly (is always a good practice to calibrate printer results and not design to compensate for that, I guess)

comments.text: It removes Z axis wobble in Y axis direction (this is the main purpose of this mod).

description.text:
Six sides with box joints that can go together to make a cube with each of the digits; 1- 6, the names of the numbers spelled, and groups of shapes with the same number of sides as the number.
The small elliptical shape a few millimeters from each side is a signal for a filament color change. You can watch the printer head and pause after it quits going to the ellipse to avoid pausing too early.
Thanks to the Brookfield Public Library in Illinois for their great 3D printing program, 3DP Club and wonderful staff.

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.02mm per layer

Infill:

10% - 2 shells

Notes:

Printer was set at the default settings for speed, acceleration, jerk & such.

Assembling the Number Cube

These were designed so the box joints print so as to go together with a TIGHT fit on the Makerbot Replicator 2 at my local library. The first layer always oozed out slightly wider and had to be removed with an X-acto knife or filed off with a nail file. Once that is removed, the sides can be pressed together and will stay without glue. If it's for a child under 3 yrs old, it should be glued together for safety.

Designed on TinkerCad...

using the basic shapes, numbers, letters, holes and a corner edge rounding hole that I made with a box and a quarter round hole. I rotated elements a few degrees in various ways in order to show the top few layers' "grain".

description.text:
The G18c (cm030) is a really nice airoft AEP, but in a fast combat its really hard to aim very precise. Since we are often playing CQB with 0,5 J only and I don't want to buy a gun above 100 € with 0,5 J I decided to create a fore grip to increase accuracy.
So maybe it's not the prettiest solution but it's mounted easily and fast.
Perhaps you have to screw it in and out a few times carefully in order to achieve a smoother thread. At the first time do it piecemeal to avoid breaking off the screw at the grip.
Three different mounts and grip lengths available!

Grips updated for better hold!

You can find the picatinny rail here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2481034

description.text:
A 10mm X-Carriage for the Hypercube EVO, drawing heavily from the original 8mm carriage design, along with influences from the Prusa i3 MK2 X-Carriage.

Bill Of Materials:
1 off LM10LUU bearing.
1 off LM10UU bearing.
5 off 100mm x 2mm zip ties (the holes are 4mm wide, and so may accept other sizes).
4 off M3 x 12mm pins (carriage/extruder mount alignment pins).
14 off M3 nuts. Square nuts are preferred for the hotend/sensor clamp.
2 off M3 x 10mm bolts (optical sensors).
6 off M3 x 12mm bolts (belt adjusters & cooling fan nozzle mount).
2 off M3 x 20mm bolts (hotend/sensor clamp),
1 off M3 x 25mm bolt (carriage to extruder mount fixing).
2 off M3 x 30mm bolts (belt clamps).
1 off E3Dv6 hotend.
1 off 12mm sensor.
1 off 50mm blower fan.
1 off part cooling fan nozzle from original Hypercube EVO post.

Once printed,

  • Clean out the belt guides with a small flat file.
  • Enlarge the 4 alignment holes only on the X carriage to 3mm using a 3mm drill bit.
  • Enlarge all the other holes to 3.2mm using a 3.2mm drill bit.
  • Push/hammer the pins into the appropriate holes on the X carriage.
  • Push/hammer all the nuts into their respective holes.
  • Pop the X carriage onto the rails, upper LM10LUU 1st.
  • Fit the zip ties with heads facing away from the carriage (see photo), tighten and trim.

Note that this carriage is 6mm wider, and the nozzle 2mm forwards, compared to the LM8UU version. Make sure you use the modified X end-stop flags, or the sensors will not trigger.

If you like my work, please consider a small donation.

author: romanlences

description.text: Quadrocopter Crossfire Cap

Update 18-01-18
I have been asked to explain how the parts fit together.

If you look at the first picture above you will see how the red and blue parts are fitted.
The endstop micro switch is mounted on the endstop mount as shown in the second picture. The M3 nut is inserted in the slot in the back of the endstop mount.
Before fitting the endstop mount insert the M3x70 screw into the Adjustable mount V2 and fit the spring to the screw. Fit the endstop to the Adjustable mount and adjust the height with the M3x70 screw. Attach the assembled parts to the frame with an M5x10 and an M5 drop in hammer nut as shown in the second picture.
The trigger is bolted to the back bed rail with the remaining M5x10 and M5 drop in hammer nut and aligned to trigger the micro-swich as shown in the second picture.

Update 17-12-23
After using the end stop since August I found that the end stop trigger was not sturdy enough and as I started off a print it finally the upright trigger broke off the base and I had to power off my printer to prevent damage to my hotend and bed.
So I came up with the latest design which strengthens the join between the upright and the base.

Update 17-08-27
Change to the picture showing the correct orientation for the limit switch mount when in use.

I was getting annoyed having to drop the bed every time I needed to make a minor adjustment to the Z height, so I came up with this design. The design moves the adjustment from the bed to the frame of the printer.
The endstop switch and fixings from the existing limit switch are re-used in my design.
The endstop trigger bolts onto the extrusion that has the lead screw mounting.
Now I can make those small minor adjustments without having to lower the bed.

Additional parts required:

2 x M5 x 10mm bolt
2 x Tslot M5 hammer nut
1 x M3 x 70mm fully threaded bolt
1 x M3 nut
1 x long compression spring or 2 x bed levelling springs, fitted to the 70mm bolt for
tensioning the limit switch

I had problems sourcing a 70mm fully treaded bolt so I purchased an ordinary bolt and threaded it myself.

description.text:
I wanted to print my own nuts & bolt for my camera and tripod.
With Fusion 3D it is very easy to create them, but once you print you have to consider also tollerances. I tried few times and at the end I found that you have to reduce the size od the nut by 0.2mm and increase the size of the hole of the same.

Do not make the same mistake of mine printing them together with cura, depending on the settings in your preferences one of the two objects will be resized, if you do not notice the pop up like me you will waste your time.

Use it and enjoy, but please if you improve it let me know.

title: Rotary/Rock Tumbler machine for polishing - (Small printer bed)

description.text:
Here is my Rotary Tumbler for polishing printed items (eg with metal filament). I've printed on a 120 x 120 mm bed size printer.
It needs to be complete (plus the printed parts):

  • motor (http://www.conrad.fr/ce/fr/product/227552/Moteur-a-entrainement----12-V----Modelcraft----RB350050-0A101R----150)
  • fuse (http://www.conrad.fr/ce/fr/product/533788/Porte-fusible-SCI-533788-10-A-250-VAC-1-pcs)
  • voltage regulator for speed control (http://www.conrad.fr/ce/fr/product/222347/Regulateur-de-tension-pour-les-moteurs-electriques-et-les-motoreducteurs)
  • power connector (http://www.conrad.fr/ce/fr/product/735640/Fiche-dalimentation-DC-Embase-femelle-verticale-Cliff-FC681445-interieur-55-mm-1-pcs)
  • 4 ball bearings 708.
    and coupleS of 8 mm bolts and threaded rods (and washers)

There is an elastic shape to print in flexible filament over pulleys to get enought traction.

With this set up, ratio 1/1 for the gear wheels, about 30 turn/minutes at full speed (with a 100 mm container), it could be modified by adjusting the ration, it should have enougth torque. There is a 20° rotation allowed for the motor mount, so wheels contact can be slightly adjusted.

Improvements planned :

  • more rigidity for the gears holder
  • lock system for the bearings (not enought tight to keep them for long hours running without glue...)

DON'T PUT YOUR FINGERS BETWEEN THE GEARED WHEELS, it hurts.....!

https://youtu.be/G7rlCeg_deg

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

I've use the fusion tools to design the gear wheels : https://apps.autodesk.com/FUSION/en/Detail/Index?id=9029586664984391977

description.text:
This is a pocket size prop balancer that you can take with you when your are out on the field flying your RC plane or quadcopter. Measures 2.25" by 4". Update 2/27/2014
New update on the prop balancer. Now you only need to purchase magnets and some threaded rod to make. There is no need to hot glue in the magnets, just press them in. I also now made the hardware for the finger balancer from threaded rod and 2 #8-32 nuts. I bought a 12" by #8-32 threaded rod from Menards. It was a $1.70. See the instructions for the details on how I made the finger balancer. Enjoy and have fun!!

25% fill, 2 shells. You will need to purchase a finger prop balancer, magnets and screw. I just hot glued the magnets but you could superglue them in too. I have balanced 5x3 and 10x5 props on this. Bellow are the links for what you need to purchase. Prop balancer Fingertip Prop Balancer GPMQ5000
http://www3.towerhobbies.com/cgi-bin/wti0001p?&I=LXK247&P=FR&gclid=Cj0KEQiA6dGmBRC_3Mi-x_XywKsBEiQA1lcFP8iU0PXH9YzuApwIVhZIdO4lEK5IeKIzfW8XvM4uSKUaAtz_8P8HAQ
Also found on Ebay. Magnets
Neodymium magnets button 8mm x 2mm size. Update 2/27/2014
Cut a piece of threaded rod to 55mm and shape to a point on both ends on a grinder. I made some nuts that you will need to print out and tap out to the same thread #8-32. I designed the printed nuts to receive a #8-32 nut to be pressed into the end of the printed nut. I printed the part to be 50% fill, 2 shells and made from PLA. I've included some pictures of the final assembly. Let me know if you have any questions. Thanks.

title: Mechanical Toilet Paper Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A unique toilet paper roll holder. Easily add and remove rolls. Insert the roll from underneath, then once the two ends are aligned with the sides of the roll, let go or pull down, the roll drops into place. Remove old roll simply by lifting up. Alternatively, you can rotate one side 90 degrees, drop the roll into it, then slowly slower it while raising the other side until it meets the roll then let go.

Prints in one piece! No assembly required. This model has an internal rotating mechanism. Print with opposite of the screw hole side facing down (the side facing you in the photo).

Uses #5 screws. Spacing requirements between installations will vary.

Can also be used for other purposes such as paper towels, aluminum foil, etc.

Note: Completely untested model, but should be sound enough to print.

comments.text: Prints fine and everything is operational (I printed standing up with supports). There is a large issue though... the "bolt" holding the flappers on is ridiculously tiny, it will snap almost immediately. comments.text: Thanks for the feedback, I expected something would likely need tuning.  Any other suggestions?  I had wondered if for example, one flap being shorter than the other could be beneficial, or if the roll would have too much space on either side to move around side to side.  Another potential route is to have one flap and just rotate that up, slide the roll on, then let it fall onto the other side where it will catch on an area.

title: GEEETECH G2S_Carriage_Belt_Clamp & Base for G2S 3-Bearing Carriage by wbrucem

description.text:
This is a REMIX of of one of the components for Bruce Moore's (wbrucem Framingham, MA) awesome G2S 3-Bearing Carriage. A couple of people including myself have commented that the carriage belt block and clamp can fail in the current configaration particularly if printed in PLA or ABS and put in a heated enclosure or using heat lamps as I do. Essentially I have just beefed up Bruce's belt block and clamp so that it doesn't have a weaker point in the centre where the bolt runs through it. I have printed these in poly carbonate and I cannot break the clamp by hand and it is unaffected by the heated enclosure.

Not a necessary upgrade for everyone unless you want to add heat. My hat goes off to Bruce for creating the original files which make a truely great upgrade to my G2S.

title: Cat and Dog Food Divider for 800g Tin Cans

description.text:
Conventional pet food gadgets only divide the food within the tin can. In high cans it is a big problem then to get the first portion out of the can.
The dispenser provided here enables it to divide the wished amount of food and take it out of the can afterwards.

Usage: Set the divider centric on top of the opened tin can and press it down until it sits on the foods surface.
Then rotate it clockwise and a stripe of food will be cutted out and shifted upwards trough the gap. A whole revolution dispenses 100g of food. If you need 150g, for example, make one and a half revolutions.
Now you can lift the divider together with the food and empty it into the feeding dish.

Try to hold the divider always at a constant height and do not apply downforce. Otherwise the remaining food underneath the divider will be squeezed and the blade will haul too much food. If you need more than 100g make one revolution at first at constant height. Then press the divider down like at start until it touches the food surface again. Now you can continue the rotation.

This model is just under development. I would be glad to get feed back and suggestions for its improvement.

title: DJI Mavic Quadlock Support and Gimbal Protector

description.text:
Hey!

This is a QuadLock support for anything that have a slot to fit your smartphone, but also is a DJI Mavic Gimbal and Screen protector.

It's based in these things:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2303739
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2089347
But I worked on it to perfectly fit the DJI Mavic Transmitter while protecting or while holding my smartphone.

It could fit into this Mavic Transmitter box as well:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1884170

QuadLock users would appreciate to leave their cases on their phones and having their mavic transmitter protected everytime.

You have the graphics version (with DJI and QuadLock logos) and a raw version to personalize as you wish, so I left 2 different .stl and one .step archives.

Enjoy it and leave feedback so I can improve it.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I've printed it at 40% infill to make it strong so it won't have problems to hold a heavy smartphone.

For the version with the DJI and QuadLock graphics, I recommend to use only 1 side perimetre so it will be readable. For top and bottom perimetres 5 will be fine (and you won't see the infill pattern).

Use supports for the QuadLock thing, I print on Simplify 3D so they were so easy to remove.

Finally, I like to print it in TPU, because that little flexibility would help to absorb posible damages to our transmitter, and still strong enough to hold the phone.

description.text:
With this simple foldable LapRF holder you can easily adjust your ImmersionRC LapRF to the optimal angle for reception. The holder is attached to the bottom of the puck with double-sided tape and it folds against the back cover for transport and storage.

This is a very fast and simple print and it does not need any supports or post-processing. For the best durability, I would suggest using ABS or PETG filaments. I printed mine with PLA filament and it functions well but does not feel very strong. For the hinge, you will need a 5x20mm bolt with a nut and two small pieces of 1mm thick rubber (from e.g. a bike tube) to get nice smooth friction between the plastic parts.

description.text: After converting the .DXF file from the genuine designer "cdesjardins", (http://www.thingiverse.com/cdesjardins/designs, many thanks to Chris Desjardins!), I imported it into Blender through a 3rd Party Import converter. Then I lost loads of time by closing the open design to make it 3Dprintable. Therefore I deleted all the embossed text from the original design (Sorry, Chris). Then I checked the newly generated files through Netfabb and ever since all is Ok and ready to print both .STL files! And I did succesfully! The result looks fine, but the parts do not fit like a perfect jigsaw puzzle all together. The genuine drawing is too perfect for reality, so I have to file down a tenth of a millimeter off all parts. New .STL files have to be made... sorry for the dissapointments. To be printed with 15% fill, 3 shells, 0,1mm filament layer height, without raft or supports.

title: Minimal USS Enterprise D Display Stand

description.text:
I wanted to make a stand for my Enterprise D print https://www.thingiverse.com/make:375349 from the awesome collection https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1423364.

I liked the base of the stand https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1807374, but wanted a one-piece mounting point. I modified the base in Blender to remove a fair amount of area to lighten it up. I then made the holder part in OpenSCAD. I cut an angled hole into the base in Blender to accommodate the holder.

This is still a work in progress, as I left too much slack in the hole in the base. The holder is loose. I used hot glue to fill the hole a bit and anchor the holder. I plan on modifying it to tighten up those tolerances.

I designed this pen out of Sublime/mraiser's propeller and was pleased to find that it resembles the quill pens of old, so I designed an upright base to stand it in.  I find it is quite a natural shape to hold in the hand.
I've included both left and right versions, though you may need to try both to see which you like better.  My left-handed girlfriend likes the left version, but so do I, even though I'm right-handed.  That's probably just because I hold my pens weird (see pix).  In any case, it makes a nice desk ornament.

These are 150 mm tall, so they print great on a Replicator, but not so much on a TOM. Once printed, snap/cut/sand the disk off (it's just there to help it stick to the build platform). Also, both the blade and the stand are narrow enough that you can use JoeyC's script, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24195, to print two at once on a dual Replicator. Pull the cartridge out of a standard Bic pen and cut about a centimeter off the end of the ink cartridge (basically cut it a little beyond where the ink ends, so it doesn't get messy). Then slide the cartridge into the propeller blade; it should press-fit right in. Print the corresponding base, stand the pen in it, and revel in your classiness.

description.text:
I wanted to be able to do assisted leveling of my heated bed. so very much inspired by the way it's done on my Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus I designed these mounting parts, using springs and thumb nuts (actually the same as on the i3Plus).

Heated bed: https://www.gearbest.com/3d-printer-parts/pp_219241.html
Thermister: https://www.gearbest.com/3d-printer-parts/pp_228653.html
Power supply: https://www.gearbest.com/3d-printer-parts/pp_540281.html
Thumb nuts (2 set): https://www.3dprima.com/parts/spare-parts/wanhao/wanhao-i3-thumb-nut-and-spring-set/a-22267/
You should use 3 shorter (3x16) screws for the 3 non-ajustable parts.

Warning! You will have to re-adjust the Z-height as per Chapter 3 Step 1 in the manual. Compared to the default 'glass bed' I lost 19 mm. and now have a build height of 312 mm.

Customizable landing gears for your Phantom 2, standard, vision or plus.

Consider the print settings below for sufficient stability!

Depending on the camera and gimbal you want to use, the standard gears may be too short. If you don't want to attach a camera at all, you may want even shorter landing gears.

The additional clip can be used to improve stability and reduce vibrations.

When I upgraded my Prusa i3 to have dual extrusion, I wanted to keep the extruder motors statically mounted so as not to weigh down the hot-end carriage. My solution was to mount them on the top of the frame of the printer at a 45 degree angle above the horizontal, so as to maximize the radius of curvature of the PTFE tubing as well as reduce the changes in curvature (i.e., the tube stays relatively straight down when the motors are mounted at 45 degrees). Note that the mount does not actually "attach" to the printers frame, but rather sits on top of it and stays on due to the clip-like shape of the mount.

I used M3x14 screws, M3 washers, and M3 locknuts to assemble the mount and also to mount the motor brackets to the mount.

I designed this so that I am able to fine-tune the tension in my x-axis belt. The stock pulley is installed in the tensioner and an M3 nut is placed into the end of the tensioner, which slides into the slot in the axis mount. An M3x25 screw with an M3 washer then goes through the back of the axis mount, into the back of the tensioner, and mates with the nut. Then, simply turning the screw pulls the tensioner closer to the back of the axis mount, pulling the pulleys back, and increasing the tension in the x-axis.

title: Non Slip Screw-on Extruder Button for Anet A8

description.text:
Rather than being clamped on the extruder release screw, this button is attached to the idler arm with the provided screw. It never falls off or wiggles in place. The button is quite grippy due to the ridges at the top.

It works perfectly together with Anet A8 alternative 40mm Extruder Fan Mount.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print it with 2 perimeters to save some material.

Step 1: take the screw out

Use an M4 wrench or pliers to release the nut and take the screw out.

Step 2: insert the screw into the button

Take the nut off of the screw and insert the screw into the button. It's a very tight fit so most likely a hex screwdriver will be handy.

Step 3: attach the button to the idler arm

Screw the button to the idler arm and use a hex screwdriver to tighten it.
Congratulations, you can now change filament without hurting your fingers!

remixed_from.author: KentAsplund
remixed_from.title: HPD F1 V2.0 A competition grade R/C car

title: HPD F1 V2.1 A competition grade R/C car

description.text:
Time for Version 2.1

This is a refinement of the V2.0 aimed at making it look nicer and handle better on low grip and super high grip circuits.

List of changes:

  • New front with separate body.
  • Front chassis now has 4 degree caster
  • The crash resistant rear wing is included
  • "0" degree camber front arms.
  • Slightly modified motor pod.
  • Minor changes on details.

The new design causes a lighter front end but it is also less crash resistant ( less material ) which puts more responsibility on you as print settings and material choice now matters on this part.

The result is a slightly less "pointy" car which is good on slippery tracks (obviously) but also on super high grip circuits where the smallest slide might cause a roll.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Notes:

Material choice is very important for durability. Best results have been achieved with Esun PLA+ and PrimaSelect.

Bumper, wing adapter and rear wing mount

These parts are intended to take up shocks from crashes and should be made in something flexible. It needs to still be fairly stiff so do not use the softest versions.
I print wing adapter and wing mount with 100% infill but make the bumper with 0.8mm shell and 5% infill.

Front arms and motor pod

These parts need to be crash resistant and not be too flexible. The motor pod also need to resist 70 degrees.
Use Nylon (Alloy 910).
Infill 100%

Bodies

0.4mm line width 0.2mm layer thickness.

The rest

0.45mm line width and 0.2 mm layer 100% infill.

Support

Most pieces are possible to print without support with following exceptions:

  • Main chassis.
  • Steering hub.
  • Rear axle.
  • Rear wing.
  • Front wing.

Needed hardware

General stuff

M3 screws in different lengths 6/10/12/14mm
M3 Nuts
Tyres and wheels
2 * M4x20mm counter sunk screws

Rear Suspension

Appropriate spur gear (90T 48pitch) and diff balls.
Pinion (30T)
Ball bearing 10x15x4mm 2pcs
Ball bearing 8x12x3.5mm 2pcs
Axial bearing 4x9mm
Diff washers from X-ray or Serpent F1 (Serpent: 41186, X-ray:375080)
M4 threaded rod 150mm
M4 nylock nut 3pcs
G20 (3/4") 2mm thick hose gasket
48.5 mm shock absorber (Hobbyking: 9655000144-0)

2x front springs Xray/Serpent/etc. (X-ray: 372180)
2x side springs Xray (373585)

Front suspension

M4x30mm screw for front axles
brass tube. 4mm inside 5mm outside for front axle.
turnbuckles and ballends for steering
Ball bearing 5x10x4, 4 pcs

The usual stuff

Low profile servo
Servos saver (optional)
Electronic speed control
Motor (21.5T is recomended)
Radio,
Short LiPo.
Charger

The new differential outdrive and indrive is designed around a new gasket acting as spring and friction. It is accepting most, maybe all, differential plates and have been tested with serpent, hobbyking and x-ray.

Differential

It might be tricky to find the appropriate gasket/packing but it is well worth the effort as this gives a very smooth differential. The packing/gasket is named "G20" or "3/4 inch" and has to 2mm thick to work appropriate. the one we use in Sweden is made by Gelia and sold on Clas Ohlsson 30-7372

If you find other sources of this component in your country please put a link in the comments below

Assembly of rear axle

The following video is showing the principle of assembly of the rear axle. It is with the components of a previous version.

Assembly of chassis

This is a video showing how to assemble the V2.0. The difference in procedure is slight (4 pieces on the front) and will probably be easy to figure out.

Participate and support

You may help and support by:

  • Testing and giving feedback (on discussion forum linked above)
  • Developing your own variant of components. Tag the item with HPD_F1 so that others can easily find it.
  • Post competition results and pictures. Here or on the forum.
  • Donate something through PayPal

Option parts and variants

See:
Thingiverse tag=HPD_F1

Tuning tips

These are the tips from the "Works Team".

Main damper

We are using 450cst oil and soft springs, I am usually using the softest spring in the series.

Side damper

Is not supplied with the kit but a relative hard damping is used. On the ones that are using plate damping (soon to be released) we are using 100 000cst.

Side springs

On a high grip circuit it you can go harder and on a low grip circuit softer.

X-Ray:
373584 C=0.6 - SILVER
373585 C=0.9 - GOLD
373586 C=1.2 - BLACK
373587 C=1.5 - SILVER
373588 C=1.8 - GOLD

Starting point for springs are the 0.9 (Gold) which works very well on slippery circuits.

Front spring

X-Ray:
372176 C=1.5 - GOLD (SOFT)
372177 C=2.0 - SILVER (SOFT)
372178 C=2.5 - BLACK (SOFT)
372179 C=3.0 - GREY (SOFT)
372180 C=3.5 - GOLD
372181 C=4.0 - SILVER
372182 C=5.0 - BLACK
372183 C=5.5 - GREY

The 5.0 spring is a good starting point.

Ackerman

You can adjust ackerman by using different holes on the steering hub. The holes furthest out is giving the most ackerman and thus most aggressive steering.

Differential

The smoother you set the differential the more forgiving the car will become. Setting the differential so soft that it is starting to slip is a good idea when you have slippery conditions. Just remember; it is plastic on plastic inside and too much heat will cause a meltdown.

On track

This is a film of the HPD V1 that shows the performance fairly well:

2017 3D printed F1 meet-up

The following film is made by Daniel Norée and shows his OpenRC, two HPD V2.1, the HPD Lexan, a hybrid between HPD V2.0 and a new design and a Hybrid between a commercial and 3D printed.

Changelog

2018-01-02.

  • Replaced amf with stl.
  • Updated the motor pod with a lower set of holes for the rear wing.
  • Renamed the front chassis to reflect the caster angle (for future variants).

This is full range reed for Soprano Saxophone Bb with concerto range A3b-E6 (frequency range 207-1318 Hz). Proper articulation and embouchure is required to cover the full range, but it is reachable with ease.
Print with as high quality in Z as your printer and heatbed cover allows. I printed reeds with Z-layer 0.04 mm and initial layer 0.12 mm. This provided 3 layers for 0.2 mm tip thickness and smooth surface. The reed shouldn't be sand-papered, since it already has required vamp profile. It may be post-processed with acetone (since this model is for ABS only by design), but I did not try acetoning myself.

Updates:

  • 01/01/2018 - Added modified 2.0 hardness reed. It is more reliable in highest notes, and 0.1mm thicker. Added modified 2.25 hardness reed. It is +0.1mm thicker than 2.0. Added 2.5 hardness reed.
  • 01/03/2018 - Added 3.0, 3.5 hardness reeds.

This is my rough version of a vortex cooler. When putting compressed air into the inlet tube cold air will exit from one end and hot air will exit from the other. This takes a lot of air. You will probably need at least a 5 gallon air compressor as this requires a large amount of flow at about 90 psi air. With 90psi air the cold exhaust will be about 25 degrees cooler than the input air and the hot side will be about 15 degrees warmer. The temperatures can be adjusted a little by pushing the hot end cap in or pulling it out slightly. Here is a sciencey explanation:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vortex_tube If anyone knows more about how to improve this design I welcome your comments. I made this with no science involved with the design and was happy to have pretty good results.

1) Print the three parts.
2) Attach the cover to the cold end of the tube using 4 3mm x 6mm screws. (you also may want to superglue it on to make it air tight)
3) Slide the cap onto the hot end of the tube. You will need to almost press the cap against the tube blocking most of the opening.
4) Thread the two small holes on the sides of the tube to a 10-32 thread.
5) thread two push in connectors into the newly threaded holes. (Mcmaster #5779K241)
6) Insert a small length of 1/8" od hard tubing into the newly attached fittings
7) Push the other ends of the 1/8" od tubes into a reducing T-Fitting (McMaster #5779K665)
8) Insert a small length of 1/4" od ard tubing into the larger opening on the T-fitting.
9) Flow 90psi air into the 1/4" tube and adjust the cap until cold air starts to come out the cover end and hot air comes out of the cap end. (note that the cap will appear to almost block the hot end but will allow enough hot air out to cause cooling on the cold end)

comments.text:
The cylindrical pipe should be metal to conduct heat out of the swirling air inside.
If the metal has fins on the outside to dissapate heat then that would be good too.
Thirdly, the air should enounter a ramp - like it's going to do a Dukes of Hazzard stunt - just at the point where the nozzle on the inlet opens up to inside the swirl chamber. the ramp should start at the periphery of the chamber and head towards the centre. the ramp should be the width of the inlet nozzle plus 30%.

description.text:
I was having some stepper overheat issues on complex prints, so having some old 80mm PC case fans laying around, I decided to make a small adapter to fit them over the motherboard. Intended to screw onto the side of the P802's motherboard plate with M3 screws. The holes were a tiny bit misaligned for my board, but they still fit and installed in perfectly. Haven't had issues since then!

The shrouds on the side were designed as I had it blowing air almost directly on the bed and it's rerouted itself in a way that not as much air is blown over the actual heating bed.

I could've designed it to use less filament, but I honestly couldn't be too bothered, it serves its purpose!

title: DJI Phantom 3 Camera Lens Hood - Parasoley

description.text:
DJI Phantom 3 Camera Lens Hood - Parasoley

What good is the hood? The primary use for a lens hood is to prevent light from hitting the front lens element from the sides - reducing contrast and creating flare. Pictures taken with a lens hood installed can have richer colors and deeper saturation.

A secondary use for a lens hood is to protect the lens. The damage prevented can range from a finger-printed front element (a minor inconvenience) to a broken front element (possibly a major expense - and lost pictures/downtime). Lens hoods are generally strong and stick out from the lens some distance. Accidental touches and scratches to the front element are reduced simply because the glass is more difficult to reach with the hood in place. Some impact protection is gained from having a sacrificial part taking the blow. Of course, ultra wide angle lenses have very short hoods that offer very little protection.

Lens hoods on longer focal length lenses offer more front lens element protection from rain and dust. Of course, if your lens is not weather sealed, you should not let it get wet in the first place. A clean and dry front element will allow the camera to deliver the better image quality you expect.

This lens hood compatible Phantom 3 Professional, Advanced and Standard models.

remixed_from.title: MP Select Mini Combo Filament Filter and Guide

title: MP Select Mini Combo Filament Filter and Guide - Revised with Guide Ring

description.text:
MP Select Mini Combo Filament Filter and Guide - Revised with Guide Ring

This is for the Monoprice MP Select Mini, a filament guide and filter combined but this time I added a guide ring.

The original filter guide I made is fine but just wanted to add a better guide to it.

You will find the filter box is tight to open, it's made that way as just opening and closing it a few times will loosen the clasp. You don't want the clasp very loose as I found that the filament can actually pop the box open.

Printer:

monoprice mp select mini

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

your choice

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Originally I did 20% infill but found that after a while the guide started to bend from the filament pulling down on it so I found that at least 50% infill stops that.
I wanted a nice looking part so I used .1 layer height which came out very nice.
Supports, yes just touching buildplate for the top of the filter box.
For raft just use brim to make sure it stays in place as it's rather thin.

Note to install.

Clean can be a pain for the ring, for it to rotate freely you need to make sure it's very clean so you will have to spend time doing clean up. I used sandpaper, x-acto knife and small files, but you can use whatever you have on hand.

Notes for installation... Yes you can use existing screws to attach bar to printer. The screw holes slightly smaller so you may have to remove some material, better to be smaller than too large, easier to remove than add material as it were. I just used an X-Acto knife and spun it around the holes top and bottom a few times and it removed enough material, just a few seconds really.

The bottom of the box is cut to allow the screw to go in, but the top is not. You have to install with the box in the open position.

description.text: The original filament cooling fan in the FLSUN delta printer is inadequate, and even a stronger replacement does not provide enough airflow. Since I couldn't be arsed to design another carrier I made a couple of pieces to install a 40mm fan I had at my disposal. It's not the most elegant setup but it works.

FLSUN Delta

Rafts:

No

No

0.18

20

Use 3 layers thick perimeters.
Wrap a bit of scotch tape to the end of the chimney to ensure a decent seal. Also, a bit of painter's tape helps with the fan endpiece sealing.

author: LionFox

description.text:
One evening I was thinking about printing Meis Hairpin and to my honest surprise I could found none models that I could call "good".

So I made it myself. Took me 2 hours or so.

I strongly advice not to print small balls. Find 2 10 mm beads instead. 3d printers and spheres don't go together very well.

14.10 update. So after test print I decided to make ball slightly larger, also cut needle in half for folks with small printers. Also holes in topper and star a little bigger, should help with printing.

comments.text: how did you attach the smaller ball pieces to the star and keep it connected? i see a small hole in the small balls and was wanting to know how it is supposed to attach
comments.author: ladyneko911

comments.text: Hi. You should use tiny piece of fishing string to connect star and small balls together. White sewing string should work too. Also I recommend not to print small balls and use 10 mm beads instead. It would looks better and save you time.
comments.author: ladyneko911

title: USB + HDMI Bracket for Oculus Rift

description.text:
I needed a USB3 and HDMI port for my Oculus Rift on the front side of my desk.
Easy - I have a 3D printer! :)

This bracket is made for an Amazon Basics 3.0 USB extension and a kwmobile 4K HDMI Repeater. It is a tight fit so the repeater and the USB port stay in the bracket when I push or pull the plugs..

I made two versions. One is a flush mount, the other one is a little bit recessed.

EDIT:
I have added a third version. This can be screwed flat under a table.

comments.text: any chance you could make a flush mount version ?
comments.author: xcooling

comments.text:
Ok, done!
Give it a try!
comments.author: xcooling

comments.text: I understand what he was asking now, he meant a flush mount vertically. So you could mount this just under a flat front edge desk, that doesn't have the brace to go around.
comments.author: blecheimer

comments.text:
Oh!! Now I understand!
No problem, that is easy - the new version is uploaded in one minute. I will call it "flat mount".
comments.author: SaskiFX

comments.text: thanks, but i think u uploaded the same one.
comments.author: blecheimer

comments.text:
The new version is 3.5mm longer and can now be flush mounted with the desk.
If you need something else, please give me more info.
comments.author: xcooling

title: CR-10 / CR-10S X axis right side cover

description.text:
UPDATE : I made a CR-10S version available, as well as in/out (or no) text. Happy printing!

DISCLAIMER: IT'S JUST GOOD LOOKING!

If like me you don't plan on upgrading you CR-10 with an X axis tensioner, but still wish to pimp that side of your printer, then this is just for you!

It doesn't get in the way of the belt or the extruder and is just nice if you don't like the bare metal look of your printer. Simply glide it from right to left and you should be good.
I suggest printing it on the right (hollow) side of the shield to avoid wasting material in support The cleanup is also much more easy.
I made it to train myself using Fusion 360 and calipers, so if it isn't perfect just let me know, I would be interested in making it better. If you have ideas on how to make it useful, let me know too!

I was inspired by the Y-pulley and the left side X-pulley cover from clavenmoo : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477621 (link to the Y-pulley cover)
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2475990 (link to the left side X-pulley cover)

I really like these for the good look they give to my printer, so thanks a lot clavenmoo!

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Higher is better

Infill:

15-30%

comments.text:
Very nice model!! Could you please add a version for CR-10S? (sorry, I just received my 10-S and was not able to stop printing and start to create models).
Thanks a lot.
Douglas.

comments.text: I just checked on the internet and it seems that the CR-10 and CR-10S do not differ in size for this. Can you try printing my model? I'm pretty sure it will fit nicely. Tell me if it worked :)
comments.author: douglas713

comments.text: Sorry. I meant to add a "S" to the logo. I would really appreciate you to upload this version with the logo "CR-10S". Thx a lot.
comments.author: Mars1307

comments.text:
Hi. I just printed it out, but it does not cover the hardware completely. Maybe add more 10mm would solve that.
What do you think?
Thank you ver much.
Douglas.

comments.text:
Hi! Thank you for your suggestion. I made an extended version for each one of them. The text is also larger so it should print a little bit better.
I see in your picture that you printed with the text pointing down, you can try (if you want of course :) ) printing it with the right side of the shield as the base, like in my picture. The text should appear a little bit better.
Tell me how it went!

comments.text: now it fits perfectly. thank you very much!!!!

author: ZZzz

description.text:
I bought an mk8 dual extruder before I knew I wanted to build a d-bot. Once I started building I decided I didn't want the dual extruder to go to waste, so I designed this carriage to hold the dual extruder in place of the extruder used in the d-bot guide.

The mk8 also allows me to augment the extruders to work with flexible filaments, which the d-bot handles like a pro.

Overall the setup is heavier than I would like, but I have been running the printer everyday for almost 4 months now and it has yet to skip once, so it can't be that big of a problem.

This carriage works in such a way that a single extruder mk8 should also fit.

Please feel free to reach out if you have any questions for me.

title: Anet A6 Back Frame, Stabilizer and Motor Fixation
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This back frame bracket is a deep redesign remix of following parts from Henkolizer and MonkeyDudes:
-https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912107
-https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2284888

Changes performed are:

  • Wider bracket to properly anchor the X axis. Now, bracket touches both sides of structure to make it stiffer.
  • Two holes have been added to also anchor the bracket to the central cross bar to avoid any bending.
  • A flat surface has been added to fill the gap between central crossbar and the platform in which the printer is placed.
  • Some model errors have been fixed which caused rare slicing issues.
  • Some parts have been lightened in a beam way to reduce the ammount of material and the printing time.
  • Dimensions have been checked and fixed to meet the printer dimensions and to ease the assembly process.
  • Four vertical reinforcements have been added to increase the stiffness. EDIT: a new version without two vertical center reinforcements has been upload to ease the assembly (the original one can be mounted perfectly, but the new one allows more space to use the wrench without any obstacle).
  • Motor stop bracket shape has been changed from a rounded one to a corner in order to ease the print. EDIT: In case you prefer not to rewire cables from right side a slotted version has been uploaded.
  • Bridge parts have been rounded to avoid using any support.

I printed it in PLA and it works perfectly. You obviously need to rotate the part 45º to print it.

After printing, some sanding might be needed, however, you can use the horizontal expansion in Cura (or equivalent in other slicers) to adjust according to your printer calibration. Remember that negative values of horizontal expansion add clearance and positive values increase the perimeters.

It is highly recommended to make the part to be tightened in order to increase the stiffness. For center cross bar assembly I used M3 x 20 mm screws. Obviously, you can screw the whole bracket to the platform by using M4 countersunk screws.

I appreciate any feedback. In a future version I will move the vertical reinforcements to ease the assembly, although it is very simple.

Hope you enjoy it!

Printer:

ANET A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

You can print it at lower layer heights, I chose 0.3 mm in order to minimize the printing time as well as obtaining a higher strength. I also used three shell walls. Printed in PLA.

Instructions

As said, adjust the horizontal expansion in cura (or other slicers) according to your knowledge of printer calibration (I use -0.1 mm because my calibration cube showed this deviation). It is preferred to make the part a little bit bigger and after printing sand a little than making the piece smaller and worse the stifness of structure, which is one of the main goals of this remix.

In case you're planning or you have a printer enclosure with high ambient temperatures it is preferred to print it in other materials such as PETG. The temperature of heated bed does not affect the PLA of bracket since the gap is more than enough, although it is always advisable to use a thermal insulation at the bottom of heated bed.

To assemble it just unscrew the cross bar nuts, place the bracket properly (some sanding might be required) and screw again the nuts. After this, mount the two cross bar screws. I removed the linear bars for this assembly.

description.text:
The hurricane in the US got me thinking about useful things to have for disasters especially where there may not be clean water available for some time.

I had this idea many years ago while as an adventure guide for a better dirty or salt water distiller but it never got past a successful backyard experiment. It's simple to put together with normal household items and some 3D printing. It's also simple in function though in emergency situations 'simple' can be good!

It works under most of the same general principles as solar water distillers with one important exception, it uses a sponge to increase the air to water surface area many times over and hence it can evaporate the water much faster than a standard evaporative distiller.

The sponge holds all of the water with little to no water outside the sponge which significantly reduces the chance of accidentally contaminating the clean water. Not only that, the bowl is very bottom heavy so it's unlikely to tip onto its side, and if it does the bowls design means it will hold the water still.

You'll need the following:-

  • the printed bowl (choose between 5mm or 1/4-20 threaded rods)
  • the printed 4 flat disc like nuts for the above or use standard nuts with washers
  • the printed bag clip
  • round sponge/s to fit base of bowl and be up to 25mm high - a cut up towel can work at a pinch
  • large clear or dark opaque garbage bag
  • plastic bottle top and cap - see video below - Note: not my video
  • a piece of string

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I suggest printing these items with 3 perimeters in an improved PLA or other tough filament such as ABS or PETG.

Assembly
  1. Cutout sponge to fit neatly into base - if your sponge doesn't fit then maybe use a towel cut to size in layers under the sponge. You'll need to make holes for the threaded rods to pass through.
  2. Screw in the nuts to secure the sponge with a little bit of compression.
  3. Fill with the suspect or salt water but don't let it become completely saturated. Set aside
  4. Take cut out plastic bottle (as per video below) and locate at centre base of plastic bag. Cut a small hole and tease through and out of bottle top. Place cap on firmly and test for water tightness by add some water to the bag.
  5. Carefully add the bowl to the bottom of the bag.
  6. Take the top of the bag and fold in half across the top and again and again until it will fit neatly folded into the large bag clip. Attach clip.
  7. Tie through hole in bag clip to something in full sunlight such as branch or clothes line. Carefully open the bottle again and blow into bag until it's taut and screw back on.
  8. That's it! Occasionally check during the day and empty any distilled water and fill up dirty water as needed.
This is an example of what I mean with the plastic bottle - Note: It's not my video

title: Elbow Joint modification for Unlimbited Arm

description.text: The elbow joint of the Unlimbited Arm can come apart if enough force is applied, according to some user feedback. Whilst the original pins should be good if the joint is correctly aligned, it can happen anyway. Some suggest using Chicago screws, but these are not available in some countries (like mine). Also, they do not allow a fail-safe break in the event of the user having a fall. I wanted to make a simple solution using stainless steel screws (this uses a #6 self-tapping, countersunk head screw, ½” long) and a plastic component that will break if the force is too strong such as might happen during a fall.

Printer:

Colido 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Same settings as original parts.

Give the recipient a few spare stars in case they fall and break them.

Design notes:

The prosthetic limb parts are sized and imported from the Team Unlimbited Alfie Arm by entering the basic sizes into their parametric Customiser. I designed the modified parts in Alibre, and then used TinkerCad to apply the mods to the downloaded parts. Consequently these mods are not sized in relation to the limb, but rather made for a #6 screw. If you are using a different screw, then the mod parts would need to be scaled accordingly.

Designed for Manon :*

This is a shelf support in several sizes for actual use.

Because FDM 3D prints are (much) weaker in the Z-axis, the design was made to be printed horizontally. For this reason the diagonal brace has only the thickness necessary to be an effective support without interfering when mounting the support.

Print with a decent infill and shells this is actually quite strong.

Please use screws with FLAT heads, not the conical ones that are used for wood.
Conical screw tend to split the prints apart.
Screws to be uses are of the 4 mm variety with a 8 mm screw head.

I have included four different models, with brace lengths of 50, 90, 120 and 150 mm in length.

Printer:

Mankati, Creatbot

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

30%-90%

Notes:

Print this in PLA, ABS, PETG or any other strong material.
Do NOT use materials like woodfill, bronzefill or similar materials if you need the parts to be strong.

description.text:
Derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:148454 I liked the original design but couldn't find the right metric parts locally, so I reworked the design to use imperial parts that I could get cheaply from my local hardware store. Also changed it slightly so that both cone wedges are identical. Update: added printable mounting clips
Update: added generic mounting brackets (mounted a second spool on the shelf of my desk)

Print 2x of part A and 1x of part B, and 2x of part C. Part A includes support structures in the model, so print it without supports. Part D is optional and just provides a cone-shaped spacer that can be used to hold the spool away from the printer frame an extra 15mm (I found it useful for some of my spools). Part E is optional mounting bracket that can be used to mount the rod to any surface that you're willing to drill a couple of bolt holes into.  
You need a length of 1/4" threaded rod. I think mine is roughly one foot.  
Also need 2x 1/4" hex nuts, three 1/4" threaded rod couplings (these are like really long hex nuts).  
For the bearings, I used two radial bearings (these were MUCH cheaper than standard precision bearings), 3/8" inner diameter and  1 1/8" outer diameter.  
To make the bearings fit the threaded rods I used a pair of steel spacers, 1/4" inner diameter and 3/8" outer diameter.  
All of the parts were found at my local Ace Hardware, for around $10 total.  
note: I used some loctite to hold the inner hub of the bearings to the steel spacers (be careful to not get any loctite into the bearings themselves or they'll be ruined!!). I also used some loctite on the two smaller hex nuts that hold the "fixed" cone in position (the one nearer to the printer is fixed in place, although it still spins freely on its bearing). And loctite is also used on the two couplings that are held in the mounting clips - the loctite there keeps the threaded rod from turning.

This is a pretty challenging little puzzle that is relatively easy to make. You will need to print 4 blocks and paint/print the colors per the directions (see link).

There are three puzzles to be solved.

Puzzle 1 - Arrange the cubes inside the enclosure so there are 4 different colors in each side.
Puzzle 2 - Pull the cubes out the enclosure and form a 2x2 square out of the cubes. For this puzzle, you must have 4 different colors on the top and bottom, and 2 different colors in each side.
Puzzle 3 - Again, this one is outside of the enclosure and makes a 2x2 grid. For this puzzle, you must have 4 different colors on the top and bottom, and same color on each side.

Build Instructions: https://www.instructables.com/id/Instant-Insanity-Puzzle/

description.text:
This is a replacement lens/rangefinder/viewfinder cap I designed and 3D printed for the Nikon L35AF film camera.

Last Christmas I was rummaging through a cupboard and found our family’s trusty old L35AF – a rugged, 35mm rangefinder with a sharp 2.8 lens. I loaded it up with Portra 400 and went out to shoot a few rolls, but became irritated with the worn-out lens cover falling off. The rubber lens cap either wasn’t designed well to begin with, or simply wore out after years of use and abuse. Buying a cheap lens cap wasn’t a good option because it would leave the rangefinder and viewfinder uncovered.

So, I whipped up a model in Fusion 360 and printed it out of PLA. Like the original part, it covers both the lens and the rangefinder/viewfinder glass on the front. The lens cover friction-fits onto the outer part of the lens, and the rangefinder/viewfinder cover clicks into place. I was pleased to nail the lens fit on the first try.

title: Traxxas TRX4 Rock Crawling Rear Bumper

description.text:
New rear bumper for TRX4. This maximizes ground clearance over anything else. It eliminates the D-rings and trailer receiver. What it sacrifices in scale detail it makes up for in added rear clearance for climbing near vertical obstacles.

I designed it to still protect the rear edge of the stock body shell but to be very non-obtrusive. The body shell locating pins protrude through the bottom of the bumper, you can choose to either deal with it or shorten them. Currently I'm just going to let them stay, but I may modify in the future.

Its a quick and easy print. I printed it upside down with a few supports where required.

title: Slide-on ball bearing spool holder for Ikea Lack table

description.text:
Fits onto the edge of the Ikea Lack table and has holes for screws (although the friction fit has been pretty good). Uses a pair of 608 skateboard/fidget spinner ball bears and PVC pipe for the spindle.

There are two "bearing adapter" files. The one shown in the pictures is "bearing adapter 1in" which fits inside standard 1in schedule 40 PVC pipe. The other file is made to fit 3/4in PVC pipe, but I haven't printed or tested it.

After a few days of use, I found that it turns so easily it was beginning to unravel itself so I made a filament guide to go with it. Also created a version for 1in PVC that doesn't use bearings at all.

title: Replacement enclosure for the junk-cheap Chinese laser pointer

description.text:
I have bought a few extremely cheap Chinese laser pointers (for playing with the cat). The only thing is that quality of enclosures are truly bad. They have broken within an hour.
So I have made an enclosure for all what is inside.

Printer:

Raise3D N2 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.24 mm

Infill:

100%

Sanded

With 4 different roughness sanding paper and it came pleasantly smooth - it is like a fidget when you hold it in hand when sanded.

a few moments on the design

I have made the enclosure so everything slides in from the back.
Therefore the plastic cover of the button comes in first gets into its place and "hides" its pad so that the laser module slides all the way in. Then to prevent the module displacement and rotation I have inserted a piece of filament all way through the enclosure (those little side holes)

By the way you would need to connect the wire to the + contact of the laser module so it reaches the opposite end of the battery stack (in original design aluminium enclosure does that job). then the screw-in plug presses the end of + wire to the battery stack.

title: E3D Hobb Goblin GEEETECH extruder flexible filament guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Because of the design of the popular after-market Geeetech MK8 extruder it's difficult to use flexible filaments, such as NinjaFlex(tm). A lot of people have designed and published a similar thing. But this one is different. :)

This guide is made specifically for use with the E3D Hobb Goblin extruder gear. I use it because I really like it.
Because its smaller diameter the filament output sits at a slight angle towards the PC4-M6.
This guide also fixes the angle issue.
(At delta X it measures at about 1,2 mm offset to the right).

(The original straight cut gear is larger in diameter. And the original bearing has a concave surface where the filament ride on, which acts as a guide for the original gear).

Parts

  • 1x E3D Hobb Goblin, replaces original gear
  • 1x Bearing "624ZZ" - ID: 4mm - OD: 13mm - Depth: 5mm, replaces original bearing
  • A piece of Teflon tubing with the dimensions of 3mm outer diameter and 2mm inner diameter.
    • Leave long so it goes all the way in to reach the PC4-M6 pneumatic fitting.
    • Insert and cut to the shape of the guide on one end. Use a sharp, thin blade.

View on Autodesk Galley

Free source

Log:

  • Test print 1:
    • Enlarged hole for tube diameter to 3.2mm, was 3.1mm
    • Height reduced to 12.5mm, was 12.7mm
    • Location of M3 screw / spring center distance from backplate now 6mm, was 6.35mm
    • Removed logo, was to tiny to 3D print and causes top layer defects
  • Test print 2:
    • Fits, after a little clean-up of the holes. :)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk1

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

24%

Notes:

Because the extruder can get quite hot, it is advisable to use a filament that has a higher glass temperature. I have used ABS to print this thing. :)

Make sure your retraction settings are calibrated and on point.

Geeetech E3D MK8 extruder designed in Fusion 360

I have used the latest Fusion 360 as of 26-08-2017 to design this thing.
The source is free to download for personal use. And can be changed to your liking.
View on Autodesk Galley
You can find it here: Free source

NetFabb Basic did NOT find any issues with the STL. :)

title: Titan E3D - East3DGecko 35x35x10 Delta Blowers Fancap

description.text:
EDIT 25th Nov 17

Added e3ddual35-v2beta.stp it's the current final state of the fan. IT HAS AN ISSUE, I need to finish this someday. It makes quite hard to install the small nuts that hold all in place, I was planning to fix it soon, but not much time lately.

EDIT: Added Led halo ring holder. So far it works, but hey, it's a first version so mind the gap :D

I used one of the Halo Leds I bough 2 years ago for other project, the Ebay description they call them as "90MM 105 LED COB Chip SMD Car Angel Eyes Headlight Bright Halo Ring Light" So I suppose that's how to find them. Mines are blue, I would prefer other tone, but it's ok.

EDIT: Added STEP files for the 4 parts, base, left, right, ledlighthalo-holder Enjoy!

The Led holder has some zig zag as support, so you should not use support for that part and at 0.2 with 3-4 bottom/top layers it prints fine if you have good cooling to make nice sweet bridges. The led 'clips' and doesn't move (it weights so little' but if you want you could add 1 drop of glue to make sure it stays there forever.

A design based on Gudo fan design. It's a beta so expect errors, but so far it works.

The Fan model used is 35x35x10 BFB03512HHA & connected them in series because they are 12V and east3dgecko uses 24V PSU

Possible problems

  • When hitting Pause, since the firmware can't be reedited, it might hit the x0 y0. I did try to make it as compact as possible but still it would need a different assembly to remove the last part of the problem. So far it works and gives a very nice cooling.
  • Isn't totally symmetrically centered to the Hotend, just because there's no room to move the fan behind. It could be possible to make to design the fan rotated so the wings spread and there's more room for the fans, but it would need to be a 45 degrees at least so it doesn't hit the rails of the corexy.
  • The part near the hotend SHOULD be taped with Aluminium take (high temp alu tape goes up to 150C). This should make the fancap last quite a good amount of time. But still, you NEED a E3D silicon sock. Just because it gives better thermal stability and you don't need to worry about the fans hitting the heater block.

For assembly the fan uses M2.5mm screws, and to fix it to the adapter you need 2 m3 15-15mm. It should screw into the printed part, so don't force it since there's no room to install a nut.

Also remember is a first version so it might have errors.

Print test at my Twitter account
https://twitter.com/neotko/status/901438067877318660

Important. I printed this on GreenTec BDP PLA filament that can resist up to 100C without issues. Anything less than 100C (Ngen for example it's bad in my experience for this but can work for a few months) will get deformed over time, so print more than 1 set just in case.

comments.text: thank you very much for the creation I would like to know if it needs to be printed in petg or with PLA would be more than enough
comments.author: Popiko

comments.text: I printed them on GreenTec / BDP that can resist up to 100C. I never used petg so no idea :D and normal PLA fore sure won't last long, specially if the first layer it too long and the fan it's off for the first layers. After 6 days of testing it, the one closer to the heaterblock shows small marks of heat. But I didn't install the aluminium tape, on pourpose, to test how much heat it gets with the silicon sock. So, yea, this needs a 100C material to be this close to the heater block. Ofc that's the version atm, I want to change the design to fix a couple things on the future.
comments.author: Popiko
